Award.AbstractNarration: This Integrative Graduate Education and Research (IGERT) award supports a Ph.D. training program at the Colorado School of Mines to pursue integrative research and education in Intelligent Geosystems. Graduate students will be trained to add real time, adaptive, sensing capabilities to the monitoring of natural or engineered earth structures, e.g., an earth dam, a ground water system, or a geoconstruction site (tunneling, urban excavation, highway); the sensor networks employed will allow a geosystem to sense its environment, diagnose its condition, and make decisions to improve the management, operation, or objective of the geosystem. The goals are to advance the development of the "intelligent" geosystems while educating and training a new generation of leaders who are able to operate effectively in this emerging interdisciplinary area. The proposed IGERT program will institute an interdisciplinary and holistic approach to trainees. Key components of this IGERT award include: (1) a multi-disciplinary collaborative research team framework to foster team development and interdisciplinary innovation in intelligent geosystem concepts; (2) a leadership and teamwork development program to train the next generation of geosystem leaders for industry, academia and government; (3) a PhD minor in social/environmental ethics & policy to broaden trainee understanding beyond the technical challenges to the social, environmental and political aspects of intelligent geosystems; (4) a self-paced cross-disciplinary technical course using modules in intelligent geosystems; and (5) an internship with a government laboratory or industry in intelligent geosystems. These five components of this IGERT program will produce diverse, highly skilled leaders with the strong social and environmental awareness required in multidisciplinary environments. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This IGERT project was framed by three interdisciplinary collaborative research themes. The smart dams and levees research team made significant advances in imaging internal erosion through earthen embankments, both through highly focused laboratory testing and field studies, as well as with computational modeling and data-driven backcalculation or inversion of embankment properties. A new technique was developed to non-intrusively visualize ground water flow by injecting a salt tracer upstream and monitoring the resulting electrical field passively. This electrical field was found to be due to the electrokinetic effect with a contribution from the diffusion potential. The method was applied to field monitoring of preferential erosion in earth dams. Significant knowledge in internal erosion imaging resulted from an interdisciplinary team of IGERT fellows (geophysics, geology, civil engineering) that participated in embankment testing in the Netherlands and subsequent analysis of data. This particular study provided the first published work on passive seismic interferometry applied to earth embankments and the development of a novel 4D grid-search algorithm for acoustic emissions localization in both time and space, and the application of the localization results to add spatially varying constraints to time-lapse three-dimensional modeling of self-potential data in the terms of source current localization.

The intelligent geoconstruction research team pursued research to advance construction processes that can sense their environment, learn as needed, decide and execute actions. Research efforts focused on advancing understanding of machine-ground interaction, including vibratory plate-soil interaction mechanics, vibratory drum-soil interaction mechanics, and tunnel boring machine-soil interaction mechanics. Highlights include the development of a machine-integrated soil stiffness measurement system for roller compactors, a technique patented by a fellow, and the development of a vibration-based boulder impact detection system for tunnel boring machines.  

The intelligent remediation team pursued research to improve in-situ groundwater remediation by advancing methods that provide enhanced monitoring and the opportunity of real-time feedback control. The geophysical signals associated with chemical and physical attributes of remediation systems were studied in laboratory-scale batch and 2-D tank systems. An important outcome of the experiments was that fluid conductivity could be predicted within 3-6% based on the known chemical reactions. This research provided the first reported quantitative link between predicted fluid conductivity based on chemical changes imposed for permanganate remediation of chlorinated solvents and fluid conductivity measured by in-phase electrical conductivity.

The IGERT program incorporated three unique educational components that resulted in significant accomplishment, namely (1) a PhD minor in science, technology, engineering and policy; (2) a leadership and teamwork training program; and (3) an interdisciplinary intelligent geosystems course. Components 2 and 3 contributed to a fourth key component of our program, the collaboration research teams.

Thirty two (32) trainees from seven technical disciplines were supported by the IGERT project over the project period. We succeeded in recruiting and educating a diverse group of trainees. 53% of our trainees (17 of 32) were women and/or underrepresented minority students. 31% of our trainees were women (10 of 32) and 31% were underrepresented minorities (10 of 32). Both these percentages are well above the university representations.
